data.title: Turnstone Biologics Stops Tidal-01 Trials, Explores Strategic Alternatives; Shares Rise
data.description:
Turnstone Biologics said Tuesday it has decided to discontinue all clinical trials assessing Tidal-01 in solid tumors and has launched a process to explore strategic alternatives to maximize shareholder value.

The company said it has hired an advisor to help in the review of potential alternatives that may include an acquisition, merger, sale of assets, licensing, or other deals.

Turnstone also said it's reducing its workforce and implementing other cost-cutting and cash-preservation measures.

The company's shares were rising past 6% in recent trading.

data.title: Movano Starts Cuffless Blood Pressure Wearable Device Clinical Study
data.description:
Movano said Tuesday it has begun a clinical trial with its new cuffless blood pressure wrist wearable.

The company said in the study, the device will be used to monitor pulse pressure waveforms compared with a hospital grade blood pressure device and will also collect data on pulse rate, blood oxygen saturation and other vital signs.

The trial is expected to include at least 70 participants and be finished in the second week of February, Movano said.

The company said the study follows three clinical trials where it used its non-invasive devices to collect pulse pressure waveform data from more than 60 participants.

data.title: Quantum BioPharma's Unbuzzd Proven to Accelerate Alcohol Metabolism in Clinical Trial; Shares Jump
data.description:
Quantum BioPharma said Tuesday that a trial of its dietary supplement, Unbuzzd, confirmed it accelerates alcohol metabolism, speeds the reduction of blood alcohol concentration, and reduces symptoms of intoxication, impairment, and hangover.

The study, which examined Unbuzzd's impact on alcohol intoxication and metabolism, found the results to be statistically significant compared to a placebo.

The effects were noticeable within 30 minutes of consuming the dissolved powder. The supplement was well-tolerated, with no reported adverse effects.

The shares of Quantum BioPharma surged nearly 53% in recent trading.

data.title: Viking Venture Exits Penneo Stake
data.description:
Penneo said Tuesday that Viking Venture 29 and its founder Erik Fjellvær Hagen no longer hold shares or voting rights in the company.

Viking Venture was an investor in the software-as-a-service group through Viking Venture 29.

data.title: Gevo Price Target Maintained With a $14.00/Share by HC Wainwright & Co.
Caterpillar Is Maintained at Neutral by DA Davidson
These Stocks Are Moving the Most Today: Palantir, Alphabet, Tesla, Merck, PayPal, Super Micro, Spotify, Estee Lauder, and More — Barrons.com
data.description:
By Joe Woelfel

Stocks were mixed Tuesday as China retaliated against new U.S. tariffs by unveiling levies on certain American goods and opening an investigation into Alphabet's Google for possible antitrust violations.

These stocks were moving Tuesday:

Palantir Technologies soared 25% after the software company reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings that topped analysts' estimates and revenue jumped 36% to $828 million, beating expectations of $776 million. The company's U.S. business jumped 52% from a year earlier. "Our business results continue to astound, demonstrating our deepening position at the center of the (artificial intelligence) revolution. Our early insights surrounding the commoditization of large language models have evolved from theory to fact," said CEO Alex Karp. For the first quarter, Palantir said it expects revenue of $858 million to $862 million, up 36% from 2024 at the midpoint and better than Wall Street estimates of $799 million.

Tesla was up 0.9% after shares of the electric-vehicle giant slumped 5.2% on Monday. The stock closed lower after it was announced that tariffs levied on Mexico by the U.S. would be delayed by a month but before President Donald Trump struck a similar deal with Canada. The electric-vehicle maker assembles all its vehicles for the U.S. market in the U.S. but about 15% of the parts in a Model Y sold in the U.S. come from Mexico.

Shares of Nvidia, the leading maker of artificial-intelligence chips, were up 1.6%. Nvidia declined 2.8% on Monday as Wall Street gauged the potential effects of the Trump administration's tariffs on chip companies and amid continued worries over AI advancements made by China's DeepSeek.

Super Micro Computer rose 4.9%. The maker of AI servers said it would be providing a fiscal second-quarter " business update" on Feb. 11. The Nasdaq Stock Market told the company in November that it wasn't in compliance with a listing rule requiring timely filing of reports with the Securities and Exchange Commission. In early December, the company said it expected to file its delayed financial statements by Feb. 25.

PepsiCo posted fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of $1.96 a share, beating analysts' estimates of $1.94 but the stock fell 1.8% after revenue declined 0.2% from a year earlier to $27.78 billion and missed expectations of $27.89 billion. Shares fell 2.6%.

Shares of Spotify Technology jumped 11% after the audio-streaming company added more premium subscribers in the fourth quarter than Wall Street expected, helping revenue top estimates.

Merck fell 11% after the drug maker reported fourth-quarter adjusted earnings that beat analysts' estimates but issued guidance for f2025 that missed expectations. Merck said it expects 2025 adjusted earnings of $8.88 to $9.03 a share, below consensus of $9.21.

Pfizer was up 1.3% after fourth-quarter adjusted earnings of 63 cents a share topped analysts' forecasts of 46 cents and the company reaffirmed guidance for 2025.

PayPal was down 9.7%. The fintech beat fourth-quarter earnings and sales estimates, and said total payment volume rose 7% in the quarter, while payment transactions decreased 3%.

Estée Lauder, the luxury beauty brand, slumped 12% after it issued weak earnings guidance, said it expects to cut between 5,800 and 7,000 positions as part of a two-year restructuring plan, and would record more than $1 billion in pretax charges on employee-related costs.

Clorox reported a 15% drop in fiscal second-quarter sales to $1.69 billion, and said it now expects fiscal-year sales to fall 1% to 2%, down from a prior outlook for sales to be flat to down 2%. Shares of the cleaning-products maker were down 4.1%.

Earnings reports are expected after the closing bell Tuesday from Alphabet, Advanced Micro Devices, Chipotle Mexican Grill, and Amgen.

Alphabet rose 1.2% ahead of fourth-quarter earnings from the parent of Google. Wall Street expects Alphabet to report earnings of $2.13 a share on revenue of $96.7 billion, up from per-share profit of $1.64 on revenue of $86.3 billion a year earlier. Cloud growth at the company and updates on its AI investments will be closely watched by investors.

Write to Joe Woelfel at joseph.woelfel@barrons.com

This content was created by Barron's, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. Barron's is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: EU Must Accept Transactional Global Relationships, Commission Chief Von Der Leyen Says — Update
data.description:
By Edith Hancock

European officials need to manage their expectations in diplomatic negotiations against a more volatile geopolitical environment, European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said in reference to a possible trade war between the bloc and the U.S.

"This is a world where we can no longer take much for granted including the rules and norms that were built over the past 70 years," she said at a conference on Tuesday, adding that "in this hot-headed world, Europe's best approach is to remain level-headed."

Von der Leyen--one of the European Union's most powerful officials--said negotiators need a clear and reasonable idea of the world as it really is. "Don't think in terms of pessimism or even optimism, think about in terms of what is possible," she said.

The commission president said that no other economies in the world are as integrated in the same way as the EU and the U.S.

"We want to make it work, and not only because of our historic ties, but because it is simply smart business," she said. "So our first priority is now to work on the many areas where the interests converge."

Her comments come after U.S. President Trump signed an executive order on Feb. 1 placing extra 10% tariffs on all Chinese imports, as well as threatening measures against Canada and Mexico before postponing them as both countries agreed to boost border security. Trump blasted the U.S.'s trade relationship with the EU over the weekend, calling it an "atrocity" and complaining that the EU exports far more to the U.S. than it imports. He said fresh tariffs on the bloc will definitely happen.

"We know that there will be an increased use of threats and economic coercion tools such as sanctions, export controls and tariffs," commission chief von der Leyen said. "Europe will safeguard its economic and national security, but it is important that we strike the right balance," she said.

Write to Edith Hancock at edith.hancock@wsj.com

data.title: Update: Alpha Modus Sues Walgreens for Alleged Patent Infringement
data.description:
(Updates to include a response from Walgreens Boots Alliance and Alpha Modus Holdings stock's recent movement in the last two paragraphs.)

Alpha Modus Holdings said Tuesday it filed a patent infringement lawsuit against Walgreens Boots Alliance's pharmacy store chain Walgreens in the US District Court for the Eastern District of Texas, alleging infringement of its retail technology.

The company said the lawsuit claims Walgreens' in-store digital smart screens use technology covered by Alpha Modus's patents, including artificial intelligence tools that support in-store shopping with data insights and interactive advertising.

Walgreens declined MT Newswires' request for comment due to the "pending litigation."

Shares of Alpha Modus were down over 6% in recent Tuesday trading.

data.title: London-listed Ferrexpo plunges on $3.77 billion civil claim against Ukrainian unit
data.description:
** Shares in Ferrexpo down 20.9% to a two-month low of 82p,

** Miner says Ukrainian unit faces $3.77 billion civil claim in relation to alleged sale of waste products

** The unit, Ferrexpo Poltava Mining, rejects allegations on basis that there was no illegal extraction of the subsoil

** Unit intends to "vigorously defend" its position in the courts

** FXPO's operations unaffected by legal case

** Shares down ~23% so far this year

data.title: U.S. Duration Seen Attractive Long-Term, Less So Short-Term — Market Talk
data.description:
1047 ET - Duration from a long-term perspective looks attractive, although the tactical--or short-term--case for being long U.S. duration has become more challenging, says MFS Investment Management's Benoit Anne in a note. The case for fixed income is even stronger outside of the U.S., he says. In Europe, there are strong arguments in favor of both tactical and strategic exposure to fixed income given the significant monetary policy divergence between the U.S. and the eurozone, he says. The Federal Reserve paused last week, while the European Central Bank cut interest rates by 25 basis points. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

1028 ET - Germany's current political turmoil, with elections to be held later this month, should have a muted impact on German government bonds, says MFS Investment Management's Annalisa Piazza in a note. "Swap spreads have moved well in advance and are already pricing in some political and policy changes (such as more fiscal space)," the fixed income research analyst says. MFS IM expects the German bond curve to remain the go-to safe haven among eurozone government bonds in the medium term. (emese.bartha@wsj.com)

1008 ET - The euro has limited scope to recover even as hopes rise that the EU can avert threatened U.S. trade tariffs after President Trump postponed a levy on Canadian and Mexican imports, ING's Francesco Pesole says in a note. Trump's decision to delay tariffs on his U.S. neighbors could reflect domestic backlash over potential economic pain for U.S. consumers but the same isn't necessarily true for the EU, he says. Trump can afford to keep EU tariffs in place for a prolonged period, making the bloc feel some pain before striking a deal. "With all this in mind, we are somewhat sceptical that the euro is bound for a major rally." The euro rises 0.2% to $1.0364. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

0956 ET - As the threat of U.S. tariffs on imports from Canada continues to loom, the ongoing uncertainty makes it challenging for small business owners to plan and make decisions on their operations, warns the Canadian Federation of Independent Business. The association, which represents about 100,000 members, said that as both countries catch their breath Canada still needs to focus on critical changes needed to prepare for the future. This, the federation suggests, means taking the opportunity now to bring in policies that improve the investment climate, reduce taxes, slash red tape and break down internal trade barriers in the country to ensure Canada is prepared no matter what external threats come its way. (robb.stewart@wsj.com; @RobbMStewart)

0940 ET - With tariffs paused but still looming, Canada's automotive industry continues to stress the integrated nature of the industry in North America and the damage levies could cause. The Canadian Automotive Partnership Council in a meeting with Canadian lawmakers warned tariffs pose an existential threat to the industry in Canada and the U.S. and costs ultimately being borne by consumers. The industry body notes bilateral automotive trade is balanced, with Canadian exports to the U.S. at C$82 billion and imports at C$79 billion in 2023. And it stresses Canadian-made vehicles don't pose a threat to U.S. automotive jobs or production mandates: fewer than 10% of vehicles sold in the U.S. are produced in Canada, whereas the U.S. assembles about half of the vehicles sold in Canada and exports more vehicles to Canada than to any other country. (robb.stewart@wsj.com; @RobbMStewart)

0931 ET - Canada-U.S. trade uncertainty has just begun, even if a 30-day reprieve on U.S. tariffs and Canadian countermeasures has been agreed to, Scotiabank's Derek Holt says. President Trump's comments that tariffs are paused to see whether or not a final economic deal with Canada can be structured suggests the countries go into USMCA negotiations with an unrealistic timeline, the economist says. If Trump pushes for a rapid trade deal and Canada digs in over important issues, the tariff threat could be repeated. Or the next issue for the White House could be a push for an unrealistic 5% of GDP to be spent on defense spending accompanied by threatened tariffs, Holt says. "Throughout it all, whippy markets and high uncertainty will prevail and that carries a real, tangible cost to the economy and markets." (robb.stewart@wsj.com; @RobbMStewart)

0927 ET - The market doesn't look convinced that sterling is a robust hedge against the prospect of rising U.S.-EU trade tensions, Rabobank's Jane Foley says in a note. President Trump said he would "definitely" impose tariffs on the EU. With the U.S. maintaining a trade surplus with the U.K., the U.K. was never going to be prominent within Trump's tariff plans, Foley says. However, the U.K. is unlikely to be able to "side-step Trump's wrath completely." Trump seems willing to threaten tariffs to achieve more than economic policy goals. Sterling falls against the euro after hitting a four-week high of 0.8290 pounds on Monday, according to FactSet. EUR/GBP is last up 0.1% at 0.8319. (renae.dyer@wsj.com)

0922 ET - The dollar recovers some ground after yesterday's choppy session, which ended with a small decline in the WSJ Dollar Index as tariffs on Mexico and Canada were delayed. The trade war with China goes on and markets remain worried about the potential fallout of a prolonged period in which tariffs would loom over the global economy. BBH says in a report that investors should look through the noise and focus on the fact that the U.S. still has strong growth and elevated inflation, "and a more hawkish Fed continues to favor higher U.S. yields and a stronger dollar." The greenback strengthens 0.3 against the yen and is stable versus the euro. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

0918 ET - Much of the past few days has been about gauging how inflexible the Trump administration will be on tariffs; in other words, whether they're better understood as firm policy or a negotiating tool. Quick postponements of the Canada and Mexico tariffs point to the latter category, strategist Will Compernolle of FHN Financial writes. He notes China's retaliatory tariffs against the only barriers Trump has actually implemented so far don't start until Feb. 10. That "implies room for negotiation, something traders may take as a sign these tariffs will not be long term," Compernolle writes. "The trade relationship may nevertheless be scarred, but there's a sense, rightly or wrongly, the more maximalist policies will not be the equilibrium." (matt.grossman@wsj.com; @mattgrossman)

0835 ET - Treasury yields rise as the U.S. trade war against Mexico and Canada takes a pause while China announces retaliatory tariffs on U.S. exports. Inflation concerns are rising while it remains to be seen how the Fed will react to trade tensions. December JOLTS report is due at 10 a.m. ET. ADP employment data will come tomorrow, followed by jobless claims on Thursday and nonfarm payrolls Friday. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal forecast a slowdown in job creation last month, with unemployment stable at 4.1%. The 10-year is at 4.577% and the two-year at 4.257%. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

0722 ET - The U.K. might have to pick a side between the U.S. and Europe in a trade conflict even if it avoids direct U.S. tariffs, Pantheon Macroeconomics economists say in a note. "The EU has reportedly prepared retaliation should President Trump apply tariffs to the eurozone, and we doubt the U.K. could stand neutral in the middle," they say. Britain is highly exposed to global trade disruption because total exports and imports are worth 64% of GDP, the economists say. The U.K. might need to take Trump's other threats, including tax cuts and deportations that threaten to raise global inflation, more seriously given that other countries could respond with fiscal stimulus. Trump's actions would be hawkish for U.K. policy, they say. (edward.frankl@wsj.com)

0631 ET - Gold futures slip, though they remain close to all-time highs reached in Monday's session. Futures are down 0.55% at $2,841.40 a troy ounce, after hitting a record $2,872 in the prior session. Gold spot prices are flat on $2,814.43 an ounce. The precious metal is holding close to highs as the U.S. dollar weakens, ActivTrades' Ricardo Evangelista says in a note. The greenback gave up gains after the Trump administration delayed higher tariffs on Canada and Mexico for a month. That said, Washington hasn't backed down on tariffs for Chinese imports. As Beijing retaliates, the threat of an all-out trade war escalates, Evangelista says. This scenario casts a dark shadow over global economic growth prospects, naturally driving increased safe-haven demand and creating scope for further gold gains, Evangelista writes. (joseph.hoppe@wsj.com)

data.title: Publicis Guidance Leaves Room for Upgrades — Market Talk
data.description: Publicis' guidance for 2025 and the company's track record of being conservative in its initial outlook leave room for upgrades, CFRA's Danny Yeo Sze Wai says in a research note. The French advertising group ended the year with strong momentum in the fourth quarter, when organic net revenue growth of 6.3% beat expectations. "[Publicis] is targeting 4%-5% of organic growth in net revenue for 2025, similar to its guidance for 2024. However, we still anticipate upside potential given its history of being conservative in terms of providing future projections," the analyst says. Shares in Publicis rise 1.6%. (adria.calatayud@wsj.com)

data.title: Okta Price Target Maintained With a $115.00/Share by Needham
10-, 30-year yields rise as China's tariff retaliation adds to inflation concerns
data.description:
By Vivien Lou Chen and Jamie Chisholm

Yields on long-dated U.S. government debt inched higher Tuesday morning amid fears about the possible inflationary impact of a trade war between the U.S. and China.

What's happening

  • The yield on the 2-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD02Y slipped less than 1 basis point to 4.257%, from 4.263% on Monday.
  • The yield on the 10-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD10Y rose 2.4 basis points to 4.566%, from 4.542% on Monday.
  • The yield on the 30-year Treasury BX:TMUBMUSD30Y rose 3.3 basis points to 4.804%, from 4.771% on Monday.

What's driving markets

Long-term Treasury yields rose from some of their lowest levels of the year on Tuesday after China raised tariffs against U.S. energy and some vehicles, bolstering concerns that a prolonged trade war between the world's two biggest economies may increase inflationary pressures.

See also: Trump's tariff moves upend inflation expectations in financial markets and The tariff wars aren't over. China hits back over new 10% tariffs.

The overall market reaction - in fixed income and stocks - was relatively mild during New York morning trading compared to the volatility seen on Monday, when traders reacted to President Donald Trump's weekend announcement of U.S. tariffs on Mexico and Canada. Those tariffs ended up being delayed for 30 days.

The calmer tone may allow investors to turn their focus to the health of the U.S. economy. The rest of the week brings a fresh batch of labor data, starting with the job openings, or JOLTs report on Tuesday at 10 a.m. Eastern time, and culminating with the January nonfarm payrolls report on Friday. Other U.S. economic data on Tuesday includes factory orders for December, released at 10 a.m. Eastern.

"Any strength in data will further fuel the Fed hawks and help push back the expectation of the next rate cut further down the road. For now, the first rate cut is being priced in for June," at the earliest, said Ipek Ozkardeskaya, a senior analyst at Swissquote Bank.

-Vivien Lou Chen -Jamie Chisholm

This content was created by MarketWatch, which is operated by Dow Jones & Co. MarketWatch is published independently from Dow Jones Newswires and The Wall Street Journal.

data.title: Pfizer Shares Fall Despite EPS Soaring 530% in Q4
data.description:
Pfizer (PFE, Financial) stock dropped more than 2% at the start of the stock market opening Tuesday after the company posted a better-than-expected fourth-quarter 2024 earnings report. The firm reported adjusted earnings per share (EPS) of $0.63, up 530% from last year and flying far above Wall Street's view of $0.47. Total revenue grew 22% to $17.76 billion on the strength of strong COVID-19 product sales and contribution from the Seagen acquisition of $43 billion.

Investors are still cautious even though it was an earnings beat. However, Pfizer stock has since fallen 50% below its pandemic peak, and it is concerned about upcoming patent expirations and a projection that its Medicare plans will hurt by $1 billion. Sales of Paxlovid rebounded back to $727 million thanks to U.S. winter demand, but the vaccine company revenue plunged 38% to $3.4 billion, beating expectations.

Pfizer reiterated its 2025 revenue of $61 billion to $64 billion and an EPS range of $2.80 to $3.00. While analysts still differ in their outlook, they worry about integration costs, patent cliffs, and whether Pfizer can keep buoying up non-COVID growth. Wall Street has a keen eye for execution risks and a bias toward cost-cutting as well as oncology expansion.

data.title: ADNOC's US investments moved to international arm XRG
data.description:
Abu Dhabi National Oil Company's investments in the United States now sit within its new international investment arm XRG, ADNOC's CEO said on Tuesday, as the oil giant moves to build up a business focused on lower carbon energy and chemicals.

The U.S. investments are in an ExxonMobil hydrogen plant and in NextDecade's liquefied natural gas facility.

ADNOC announced XRG in November, saying it would be worth more than $80 billion.

XRG will also be the majority owner of German chemicals maker Covestro after its shareholders approved a takeover offer worth 14.7 billion euros ($15.22 billion), including debt. XRG also set up a joint venture with BP in Egypt, initially focused on gas.

ADNOC said in September it would acquire a 35% stake in a planned ExxonMobil large-scale hydrogen plant in Texas, which could also produce ammonia. In May, ADNOC said it bought an 11.7% stake in NextDecade's Rio Grande LNG export facility in Texas and entered a supply agreement.

In an op-ed, ADNOC Chief Executive Sultan Al Jaber also said the confirmation of Chris Wright as U.S. energy secretary was "a win for pragmatism, and an opportunity to reframe an energy narrative that has been far too negative for far too long".

He said growing emerging markets, the shift in energy systems and the "exponential growth of artificial intelligence" were mega-trends that would change the future and drive energy demand.

A diverse set of energy options is needed, including more gas over the next decade to power data centres and more chemicals to provide liquid coolants for such systems, he said.

"That's the thinking behind Abu Dhabi's newest addition to its energy portfolio: XRG is an international energy investment company that will focus on projects across the spectrum, from gas to chemicals to low carbon fuels to energy infrastructure," said Al Jaber, who was the president of COP28.

($1 = 0.9658 euros)

data.title: UPDATE - ATIS Launches New Emergency Communications & Phone Monitoring Solutions
data.description:
ST. LOUIS, Feb. 04, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — ATIS, a leading provider of elevator and escalator safety inspections, consulting, and managed services, is thrilled to announce the launch of its Emergency Communications & Phone Monitoring services. This service is a natural extension of ATIS' offering as a trusted advisor to manage all aspects of vertical transportation systems to ensure they are safe, compliant and operational.

Recognizing the urgent need to modernize elevator emergency communication and with regulations accelerating the timeline, ATIS responded to customer requests by piloting these services and establishing critical strategic partnerships to offer seamless end-to-end solutions. This highly effective initiative will now be rolled out to help all customers enhance elevator safety and compliance through state-of-the-art emergency communication systems.

Key Features of ATIS' Emergency Communications & Monitoring Services:

  • 24/7 Monitoring: Continuous oversight of elevator emergency communication systems.
  • Cost-Effective Upgrades: Transition from outdated landlines to reliable cellular or VoIP technology at an affordable price.
  • Code Compliance: Solutions that ensure elevator communication systems meets all safety and regulatory requirements.
  • Tailored Solutions: Customized installations designed for each building and elevator system’s unique needs.
  • Expert Consultation: A dedicated team of industry veterans providing unbiased, professional advice and support.

ATIS’ Emergency Communications & Monitoring services are available with flexible subscription packages that cover equipment and monitoring, along with a one-time, low-cost installation fee.

ATIS is proud to have industry veterans Lee Ingram and Clint McReynolds spearheading this critical service. Ingram, with over 21 years of experience in the elevator industry, will lead the Special Solutions Team. McReynolds, who brings 15 years of experience in both the elevator and telecommunications sectors, will focus on modernization, maintenance planning, and compliance.

Lee Ingram, SVP of Special Solutions, stated, "Our mission is to provide clients with reliable, fully compliant emergency communications systems. With the rapid advancements in technology and regulations, ATIS is dedicated to offering clear, transparent solutions and expert guidance to help clients navigate these complexities and ensure the safety of their elevator systems."

For more information about ATIS’ Emergency Communications & Monitoring services, or to inquire about the new service offerings, please contact ATIS at info@ascendalert.com or visit https://atis.com/consulting/emergencycommsremotemonitoring.

About ATIS

ATIS (atis.com) is one of North America’s largest providers of vertical transportation consulting, inspections, and managed services. With a team of more than 200 inspectors and consultants, ATIS provides unparalleled service across the US and Canada to more than 15,000 customers, promoting the safety and performance of nearly 100,000 elevators and escalators. Renowned for its commitment to excellence and innovation, ATIS provides expert consulting services for a wide range of projects across all sectors, including new construction, modernization, and asset management, with fully managed elevator solutions that include maintenance management and certificate management.

Media Contact:

Rachel Baker

SVP, Sales and Marketing

rbaker@atis.com

Atis.com

data.title: February US RealClearMarkets/TIPP Optimism Index Increase Slightly, Only One Component Increases
data.description:
The first look at consumer confidence for February rose from January, with the RealClearMarkets' monthly index increasing slightly to 52.0 from 51.9 in the previous month, but only one of its three components improved.

A reading above 50 suggests optimism, while a reading below 50 suggests pessimism.

The six-month outlook index fell to 51.1 in February from 52.1 in January and the outlook for personal finances decreased to 56.0 from 60.1, while the measure of confidence in Federal Economic Policies increased to 48.8 from 43.4.

The Financial Related Stress Index fell to 61.2 in February from 64.7 in January, an indication of decreased financial concerns.

The head of polling company TechnoMetrica, Raghavan Mayur, said the survey data showed a slight increase in economic confidence of Americans in February, though 77% are still concerned about inflation while 71% are worried about an economic slowdown in the next 12 months.

"Financial stress eased significantly in February," he added, but said that high food prices remain a key concern for consumers.

data.title: Lucasys Welcomes 21st Customer as More Utilities Move to Lucasys Tax
data.description:
ATLANTA, Feb. 04, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) — Lucasys Inc, the leading provider of cloud tax software for North American utilities and energy companies, celebrates a milestone moment in business growth by signing its 21st customer. The 21 electric, gas, and water utilities who trust Lucasys to manage their tax fixed asset processes represent more than $600 billion of fixed assets. Utilities around the country are transitioning away from legacy tax software to Lucasys Tax, signaling a growing trend in the utility industry.

Lucasys is built to streamline the evolving demands of utility professionals, making the shift to Lucasys Tax a natural choice for industry leaders. With implementation projects completed in as little as 4 weeks, the Lucasys team ensures a seamless and hassle-free transition.

“Reaching our 21st customer marks a significant milestone for Lucasys, reflecting the growing trend of utilities making the switch from legacy systems to Lucasys Tax. The future looks bright for our customers and the entire utility industry, and we’re excited to continue delivering best-in-class solutions."

-Vadim Lantukh, Co-Founder and CEO of Lucasys

Lucasys leadership attributes marketplace momentum to a number of factors, including its robust enterprise-grade software solutions, best-in-class support with deep industry expertise, and the recent settlement of Lucasys’ legal claims against PowerPlan.

The strength of Lucasys software lies in its intuitive design and automation capabilities. By leveraging modern technological innovations in data structures, processing routines, and application workflow, Lucasys software provides better functionality at scale than other alternatives.

Behind Lucasys' innovative solutions is a team of industry veterans with extensive business, technology, and regulatory experience. The Lucasys team, including co-founders Vadim Lantukh (CEO), Daniel Chang (COO), and Stephen Strang (CTO), brings decades of industry expertise in finance, technology, and consulting. Their combined experience ensures that Lucasys not only delivers cutting-edge software but also provides unparalleled support and industry insights to its clients.

Lucasys' commitment to excellence is further demonstrated by its responsive support and continuous improvement efforts. The company works closely with its customers, incorporating their feedback into product development to ensure that the solutions remain aligned with evolving industry needs.

Among the factors bolstering Lucasys’ momentum in the marketplace is the recent news of antitrust litigation settlement with Roper Technologies subsidiary, PowerPlan. To settle all outstanding claims, PowerPlan paid Lucasys $24 million. As part of the binding settlement, which is not confidential, PowerPlan has agreed to “not engage in any retaliation, retribution, or discrimination against any PowerPlan customer for doing business with Lucasys or any vendor of such customer”. The settlement agreement in its entirety can be found here.

Lucasys sued PowerPlan on July 17, 2020 for violations of Federal antitrust law, contract interference, malicious interference, defamation, and sham trade secret assertions (Case Number 1:20CV02987 filed in the United States District Court for the Northern District of Georgia). In exchange for the terms in the binding settlement agreement, Lucasys has agreed to drop its litigation against PowerPlan for engaging in its anticompetitive campaign against Lucasys in furtherance of its monopoly.

Lucasys looks forward to welcoming additional utilities as customers, accelerating its market share momentum, and continuing to provide exceptional value for its customers.

About Lucasys

Lucasys delivers software and technology-enabled services to empower finance, accounting, and tax professionals in asset-intensive industries to optimize the financial performance of their fixed assets and proactively meet changing regulatory and compliance requirements. With a core focus on rate-regulated utilities, Lucasys provides the industry and domain expertise utilities require to meet their business objectives. To learn more about Lucasys, visit https://www.lucasys.com or follow us on LinkedIn.

Contact: Thomas Ferguson, CMO, Lucasys

1-844-582-2797

contact@lucasys.com

data.title: TMX Group Shares Rise on 4Q Profit, Revenue Growth
data.description:
By Adriano Marchese

TMX Group shares rose Tuesday morning after reporting better-than-expected profit and revenue in the fourth quarter.

Shares traded up 7.3% to 48.55 Canadian dollars ($33.65).

The Canadian financial services company, which operates the Toronto Stock Exchange, late on Monday said revenue rose to C$393.3 million, from C$301.5 million a year earlier, largely attributable to increases in Global Solutions, Insights and Analytics, it said.

Analysts polled on FactSet expected revenue of C$372.5 million.

Earnings nearly doubled to C$159.3 million, or C$0.58 a share, up from C$84.4 million, or C$0.31 a share, last year.

The company credits net finance income of C$40 million driven by foreign exchange gains on U.S. dollar-denominated intercompany loans, up from a year earlier when TMX logged net finance costs of C$4.6 million.

On an adjusted basis, earnings were C$0.48 a share, topping expectations for C$0.44.

The board has declared a 5% increase to its quarterly dividend, which is now C$0.20 a share, payable March 7 to shareholders of record as of Feb. 21.

Write to Adriano Marchese at adriano.marchese@wsj.com

data.title: SocGen's EU Government Bonds Positioning Report
data.description:
The weekly analysis of flows into eurozone government bonds shows that in the week ending last Friday, investors were net buyers of all sovereign bonds — Germany's Bunds, France's OATs, Italy's BTPs and Spain's SPGBs, said Societe Generale on Tuesday.

— Bunds saw net buying over the week, continuing the trend of the previous week, driven by both non-domestic and domestic investors. Domestic investors were mostly net buyers of the 10-20y and 5-10y sectors, with asset managers being the most active investors. Continuing the

trend of the previous two weeks, non-domestic investors were also net buyers, mostly in the 20+y and 5-10y sectors, with banks and hedge funds leading the way.

— OATs saw net buying, extending the trend of the previous 10 weeks, driven by both domestic and non-domestic investors. Domestic investors were primarily net buyers of the 20+y category, driven by asset managers. The net buying of non-domestic investors remained on the same trend as the previous 10 weeks and was led by hedge funds and asset managers in the 5-10y and 20+y

categories.

— BTPs saw net purchasing, continuing the trend of the previous eight weeks, driven by both domestic and non-domestic investors. Domestic investors were net buyers of bonds for the eighth week in a row, mostly in the 5-10y and 2-5y categories, led by banks and asset managers. Non-domestic investors were net buyers, reversing the trend of the previous week, driven by asset managers and insurers in the 20+y and 5-10y segments.

— SPGBs saw net buying, led by both domestic and non-domestic investors, continuing the trend of the previous three weeks. Domestic investors' net buying was a continuation of the trend of the previous 17 weeks and was primarily in the 10-20y sector, driven by asset managers. Non-domestic investors were also net buyers, continuing the trend of the previous three weeks. Their net buying was mostly in the 2-5y and 10-20y categories, mainly driven by asset managers.

data.title: Global Equities Roundup: Market Talk
data.description:
The latest Market Talks covering Equities. Published exclusively on Dow Jones Newswires throughout the day.

1042 ET - Grain merchant ADM says as part of its plan to cut costs it could shutter or divest facilities that are in need of repair, have a history of poor performance or are located in areas with excess capacity. CEO Juan Luciano said on a call with investors that the company has identified about $2 billion worth of opportunities. The company is facing pressure from low crop prices and falling profit margins in its oilseed processing business. "We will execute on this over time," Luciano said. (patrick.thomas@wsj.com)

1041 ET - Light-vehicle sales in January indicate Canadian consumers are unperturbed about the economic uncertainty circling over President Trump's trade policy. Research firm DesRosiers Automotive Consultants says its data indicate vehicle sales in January rose 3.1% from the same year-ago month, and in terms of volumes matching the best January ever recorded, back in 2018. On a seasonally-adjusted basis, light-vehicle sales came at a "strapping" 2.15 million, DesRosiers says. The firm adds it's difficult to put January's performance in context, given Trump's tariff threat. As a result, DesRosiers says it's hard to discern whether strong sales were the result of fears over sharply higher car prices, or a sign of solid domestic demand. (paul.vieira@wsj.com; @paulvieira)

1038 ET - Intesa Sanpaolo's operating profit exceeded consensus and JPMorgan's estimates driven by higher revenue and lower provisions, JPM analysts say in a note. The Italian lender issued a higher-than-expected buyback of 2 billion euros and raised its 2025 net income target to well above 9 billion euros on the back of expected revenue growth and declining costs, the analysts say. "Overall, fee trends are encouraging and the slight step-up in buyback amounts welcome," they say. Shares are up 1.6% at 4.24 euros.(helena.smolak@wsj.com)

1037 ET - Canada's two railroads, Canadian Pacific Kansas City and Canadian National Railway, would be exposed in the event of a 25% tariff situation with the U.S., but RBC analysts think CPKC would be the most affected. CPKC has 41% of its revenue tied to cross-border trade, according to RBC. Sustained tariffs, the analysts say, over a longer period of time could derail its growth plans. "Moreover, we see many of the company's Investor Day growth targets as dependent on cross-border trade and therefore flag risk to long-term consensus EPS growth estimates should tariffs at current levels be sustained," the analysts say. (adriano.marchese@wsj.com)

1036 ET - After three years of underwhelming mergers and acquisition activity, 2025 may finally be the year that the market regains footing, Bain & Company says in a report. While some companies continued M&A during this time--navigating unfavorable market realities to deliver inorganic growth--many didn't have this option, the report says. Foundational shifts in technology, sector profit pools, and the broader global economy demanded a strategic response, the management-consulting firm says. "We expect that the two biggest inhibitors to deals in 2024--namely, interest rates and regulatory challenges--will ease in 2025," it adds. (nina.kienle@wsj.com)

1031 ET - Century Communities expects tariffs to have a greater impact on the remodel market, says Executive VP Jim Francescon in an interview. The Denver home builder adds that it's continuing to work with its suppliers but stressed that things remain fluid. "Typically suppliers will keep a number of months of supply on hand. So if this is just a short-term negotiating tactic, the new home builders may not even feel it," says Francescon. While the U.S. paused plans for 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada for one month, a 10% levy on imports from China went into effect today. Shares rise 2.2% to $76.29, recouping most of the previous sessions losses. (denny.jacob@wsj.com; @pennedbyden)

1018 ET - Bombardier bounces back as investors breathe a sigh of relief for the month-long pause on tariffs on Canadian imports. Bombardier's business is particularly vulnerable to US tariffs considering many of its business jets are sold to US customers. The company's shares gyrated in the run-up to Trump's tariffs, falling nearly 12% on Monday before recovering throughout the day after the tariff pause was announced. Bombardier is 4.3% higher at C$86.34. (adriano.marchese@wsj.com)

0956 ET - As the threat of U.S. tariffs on imports from Canada continues to loom, the ongoing uncertainty makes it challenging for small business owners to plan and make decisions on their operations, warns the Canadian Federation of Independent Business. The association, which represents about 100,000 members, said that as both countries catch their breath Canada still needs to focus on critical changes needed to prepare for the future. This, the federation suggests, means taking the opportunity now to bring in policies that improve the investment climate, reduce taxes, slash red tape and break down internal trade barriers in the country to ensure Canada is prepared no matter what external threats come its way. (robb.stewart@wsj.com; @RobbMStewart)

0940 ET - With tariffs paused but still looming, Canada's automotive industry continues to stress the integrated nature of the industry in North America and the damage levies could cause. The Canadian Automotive Partnership Council in a meeting with Canadian lawmakers warned tariffs pose an existential threat to the industry in Canada and the U.S. and costs ultimately being borne by consumers. The industry body notes bilateral automotive trade is balanced, with Canadian exports to the U.S. at C$82 billion and imports at C$79 billion in 2023. And it stresses Canadian-made vehicles don't pose a threat to U.S. automotive jobs or production mandates: fewer than 10% of vehicles sold in the U.S. are produced in Canada, whereas the U.S. assembles about half of the vehicles sold in Canada and exports more vehicles to Canada than to any other country. (robb.stewart@wsj.com; @RobbMStewart)

0853 ET - ADM falls 2% premarket after saying it expects an uncertain 2025 and posts a 6% decline in sales for the quarter ending Dec. 31 compared with a year ago, and below analyst estimates. ADM says operating profit at its crushing subsegment, which turns oilseeds into oils and biofuels, was 46% lower versus the prior year quarter, because of higher manufacturing costs among other issues. "With softer market conditions and policy uncertainty around the world going into 2025, we are focused on improving our operational performance, accelerating costs savings, and simplifying our portfolio," says ADM CEO Juan Luciano in a statement. (patrick.thomas@wsj.com)

0840 ET - TGI Fridays has sold more of the 39 company restaurants it declared bankruptcy on last year. The casual-dining chain sold 16 locations to franchisee Yadav Enterprises for $3 million in debt, along with curing costs, according to a court filing. Sugarloaf Hospitality, a current franchisee who is also managing the chain's hundreds of franchised locations, picked up three others. (heather.haddon@wsj.com; @heatherhaddon)

0834 ET - Diageo has had little to toast so far in 2025, AJ Bell's Russ Mould says in a note. First the calls from U.S. surgeon general for warnings about the health impacts of alcohol consumption and now it has withdrawn its medium-term guidance. The Guinness beer owner scrapped its midterm outlook of organic net sales growth of between 5% and 7%, citing uncertainty in key markets. The company said U.S. tariffs would affect the Mexican tequila and Canadian whiskey it sells in the U.S. AJ Bell's investment director says the group will be relieved to see the imposition of tariffs for these two countries delayed for now, as imports from these countries account for a good chunk of Diageo's U.S. sales. Shares are down 0.7% at 23.49 pounds. (andrea.figueras@wsj.com)

data.title: Berry Global On Pace for Largest Percent Increase In Almost a Year — Data Talk
data.description:
Berry Global Group Inc (BERY) is currently at $69.84, up $3.01 or 4.5%

  • Would be highest close since Dec. 4, 2024, when it closed at $70.96
  • On pace for largest percent increase since Feb. 9, 2024, when it rose 5.54%
  • Snaps a two day losing streak
  • Up 7.99% year-to-date
  • Down 3.42% from its all-time closing high of $72.31 on Nov. 29, 2024
  • Up 18.35% from 52 weeks ago (Feb. 6, 2024), when it closed at $59.01
  • Down 3.42% from its 52-week closing high of $72.31 on Nov. 29, 2024
  • Up 36.07% from its 52-week closing low of $51.33 on Feb. 8, 2024
  • Traded as high as $70.36; highest intraday level since Dec. 11, 2024, when it hit $70.56
  • Up 5.27% at today's intraday high; largest intraday percent increase since Nov. 19, 2024, when it rose as much as 8.13%

All data as of 10:39:55 AM ET

Source: Dow Jones Market Data, FactSet

data.title: ADM Could Close, Sell Assets — Market Talk
data.description:
1042 ET - Grain merchant ADM says as part of its plan to cut costs it could shutter or divest facilities that are in need of repair, have a history of poor performance or are located in areas with excess capacity. CEO Juan Luciano said on a call with investors that the company has identified about $2 billion worth of opportunities. The company is facing pressure from low crop prices and falling profit margins in its oilseed processing business. "We will execute on this over time," Luciano said. (patrick.thomas@wsj.com)

1041 ET - Light-vehicle sales in January indicate Canadian consumers are unperturbed about the economic uncertainty circling over President Trump's trade policy. Research firm DesRosiers Automotive Consultants says its data indicate vehicle sales in January rose 3.1% from the same year-ago month, and in terms of volumes matching the best January ever recorded, back in 2018. On a seasonally-adjusted basis, light-vehicle sales came at a "strapping" 2.15 million, DesRosiers says. The firm adds it's difficult to put January's performance in context, given Trump's tariff threat. As a result, DesRosiers says it's hard to discern whether strong sales were the result of fears over sharply higher car prices, or a sign of solid domestic demand. (paul.vieira@wsj.com; @paulvieira)

1036 ET - After three years of underwhelming mergers and acquisition activity, 2025 may finally be the year that the market regains footing, Bain & Company says in a report. While some companies continued M&A during this time--navigating unfavorable market realities to deliver inorganic growth--many didn't have this option, the report says. Foundational shifts in technology, sector profit pools, and the broader global economy demanded a strategic response, the management-consulting firm says. "We expect that the two biggest inhibitors to deals in 2024--namely, interest rates and regulatory challenges--will ease in 2025," it adds. (nina.kienle@wsj.com)

1031 ET - Century Communities expects tariffs to have a greater impact on the remodel market, says Executive VP Jim Francescon in an interview. The Denver home builder adds that it's continuing to work with its suppliers but stressed that things remain fluid. "Typically suppliers will keep a number of months of supply on hand. So if this is just a short-term negotiating tactic, the new home builders may not even feel it," says Francescon. While the U.S. paused plans for 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada for one month, a 10% levy on imports from China went into effect today. Shares rise 2.2% to $76.29, recouping most of the previous sessions losses. (denny.jacob@wsj.com; @pennedbyden)

1001 ET - The average buyer's agent commission held steady at 2.37% in 4Q, down slightly from 2.45% a year prior, according to Redfin. Despite new commission rules by the National Association of Realtors implemented in August 2024, commissions saw only minor fluctuations, starting at 2.38% in July, dipping to 2.35% in August, and returning to 2.38% by December. A Redfin survey of 500 U.S. agents revealed that 48% said the average agent commission in their area remained about the same since the NAR settlement took effect, while 43% noted a decline. Moreover, 54% of agents reported increased negotiation efforts over commissions by clients, with only 6% seeing less negotiation. (chris.wack@wsj.com)

0928 ET - New U.S. tariffs on Chinese goods were met with retaliation from China, resulting in selling in CBOT soybean futures overnight. But that selling has moderated, with the most-active soybean contract now down only 0.3% pre-market. Traders who have spoken to WSJ say that a lot of market activity has become reactive to new headlines, but is showing restraint in light of trade uncertainty. "I think the trade is well braced for this," says Terry Reilly of Marex. Reilly adds that many traders likely "learned their lesson" after handling the fallout of the trade war with China in Trump's first term. (kirk.maltais@wsj.com)

0922 ET - The dollar recovers some ground after yesterday's choppy session, which ended with a small decline in the WSJ Dollar Index as tariffs on Mexico and Canada were delayed. The trade war with China goes on and markets remain worried about the potential fallout of a prolonged period in which tariffs would loom over the global economy. BBH says in a report that investors should look through the noise and focus on the fact that the U.S. still has strong growth and elevated inflation, "and a more hawkish Fed continues to favor higher U.S. yields and a stronger dollar." The greenback strengthens 0.3 against the yen and is stable versus the euro. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

0918 ET - Much of the past few days has been about gauging how inflexible the Trump administration will be on tariffs; in other words, whether they're better understood as firm policy or a negotiating tool. Quick postponements of the Canada and Mexico tariffs point to the latter category, strategist Will Compernolle of FHN Financial writes. He notes China's retaliatory tariffs against the only barriers Trump has actually implemented so far don't start until Feb. 10. That "implies room for negotiation, something traders may take as a sign these tariffs will not be long term," Compernolle writes. "The trade relationship may nevertheless be scarred, but there's a sense, rightly or wrongly, the more maximalist policies will not be the equilibrium." (matt.grossman@wsj.com; @mattgrossman)

0910 ET - Oil futures are lower as China retaliates against U.S. tariffs with duties on U.S. exports including oil and LNG, to take effect Feb. 10. The tariff is particularly negative for WTI, says TP ICAP's Scott Shelton in a note. "I would assume with a $7 tax roughly, that arb is firmly shut and WTI will have to go elsewhere in the next few months as we go into turnarounds." U.S. refineries reduce their crude use during the maintenance season, leading to builds in U.S. crude stocks. WTI is down 2.7% at $71.16 a barrel. Brent is 1.8% lower at $74.61 a barrel. (anthony.harrup@wsj.com)

0853 ET - ADM falls 2% premarket after saying it expects an uncertain 2025 and posts a 6% decline in sales for the quarter ending Dec. 31 compared with a year ago, and below analyst estimates. ADM says operating profit at its crushing subsegment, which turns oilseeds into oils and biofuels, was 46% lower versus the prior year quarter, because of higher manufacturing costs among other issues. "With softer market conditions and policy uncertainty around the world going into 2025, we are focused on improving our operational performance, accelerating costs savings, and simplifying our portfolio," says ADM CEO Juan Luciano in a statement. (patrick.thomas@wsj.com)

0840 ET - TGI Fridays has sold more of the 39 company restaurants it declared bankruptcy on last year. The casual-dining chain sold 16 locations to franchisee Yadav Enterprises for $3 million in debt, along with curing costs, according to a court filing. Sugarloaf Hospitality, a current franchisee who is also managing the chain's hundreds of franchised locations, picked up three others. (heather.haddon@wsj.com; @heatherhaddon)

0835 ET - Treasury yields rise as the U.S. trade war against Mexico and Canada takes a pause while China announces retaliatory tariffs on U.S. exports. Inflation concerns are rising while it remains to be seen how the Fed will react to trade tensions. December JOLTS report is due at 10 a.m. ET. ADP employment data will come tomorrow, followed by jobless claims on Thursday and nonfarm payrolls Friday. Economists surveyed by The Wall Street Journal forecast a slowdown in job creation last month, with unemployment stable at 4.1%. The 10-year is at 4.577% and the two-year at 4.257%. (paulo.trevisani@wsj.com; @ptrevisani)

data.title: Quebec Labor Union Vows Legal Action After Amazon Closes 7 Warehouses, Lays Off 1,700
data.description:
The Confederation of National Trade Unions said Tuesday it is bringing legal action against Amazon.com in response to the company's decision to shut seven warehouses and lay off 1,700 workers.

"In light of the anti-union agenda behind Amazon's ruthless actions, the CSN will petition the court to annul the mass layoff and order the reopening of the seven warehouses, the reinstatement of the 1,700 Amazon employees, and the payment of compensation and damages," the trade union federation said in a statement.

Amazon didn't immediately reply to a request for comment from MT Newswires.
